reviewText:
Bloons TD 5
Bloons TD 5 is Ninja Kiwi's latest installment in the Bloons TD series. It is a strategy tower defense game with a large number of towers and maps to have fun with. I will include a TL;DR at the end.

Gameplay
In Bloons TD 5 you start off with a simple dart monkey, but as you play and destroy more and more bloons you unlock up to 17 towers to use. For single-player there are 57 maps  categorized into 5 levels of difficulty (beginner, intermediate, advanced, expert, and extreme) and there are 32 maps in co-op which are divided into 4 categories (beginner, intermediate, advanced, and expert). As you choose a map there are 4 options of difficulty (easy, medium, hard, and impoppable). There are multiple ways to play such as apocalypse, deflation, and the ability to reverse the track. Each of the 17 towers has 2 upgrade paths which each feature 4 upgrades however when you choose the third upgrade for one path the other path locks down. Each tower has different behaviors and special uses. There are upgrades which boost different part of your gameplay and buildings available for purchase (in-game money) which boost certain towers. There are special agents you can buy to give you an edge and daily challenges along with special missions. There is odyssey mode where you defend multiple tracks to get a reward. Towers even have abilities you can unlock to help give you an edge (one way or another). Bloons TD 5 is slightly addictive and packed full of content on Steam.

Graphics/sound
The graphics are polished, smooth and well-done for a tower-defense game. An interesting thing in this game is how the character icon on the bottom left changes as you upgrade your towers.

The music is simply joyful and relaxing. The only problems would be the fact the eventually you will only hear bloons popping. Luckily you can mute the sound and/or music if you want to.


Flash vs Steam version
There are quite a number of added things to Bloons TD 5 that are not included on the flash version. While the flash version is free it does not have a laboratory to upgrade your items and does not contain the Monkey Engineer and Bloonchipper. Steam has a whole new difficulty for players to face (impoppable) and does not have micro-transactions lurking in the corners. Everything on steam can easily be achieved by doing daily challenges and just playing the game. Odyssey mode does not even exist in the flash version. The only thing that flash has that steam does not is the ability to message another player in co-op. The lack of communication is a huge loss in teamwork and the ability to last for more rounds.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ 17 towers to choose from
+ 57 maps in single-player and 32 maps in co-op
+ Music is relaxing
+ Specialty building for towers and laboratory
+ 4 levels of difficulty
+ Many different ways to play
+ Monkeys vs Balloons (funny concept)
+ Odyssey mode and daily challenges
+ Missions for cash
+ Daily Reward

Cons

- No communication in co-op (this is a huge issue)
- Many people will randomly disconnect in co-op
- In co-op people idle and remove any sort of co-operation

(The main issues in this game are lying within co-op)

Final thoughts
I have always loved the Bloons series ever since I first discovered it on kongregate. This game is the highlight of the series and is amazing in almost every aspect. I love that there is no micro-transactions and there is a whole other level of difficulty. The only problem that shines to me is co-op with its lack of communication and how some people act (idling/ quitting out of the blue when you are about to win).

TL;DR
If you are a fan of the flash version this will be worth your time with 2 new exclusive towers, the new laboratory, impoppable mode, no micro-transactions, and odyssey mode. I recommend first checking out the game on NinjaKiwi to get a sense of the general gameplay and decide if you want to buy this along with all its new and fun features or not.

***Written using a key provided by the Developer***

Bloons TD5 is a fast paced, 2D Tower defense game from Ninja Kiwi. In Bloons TD5 you use an array of towers, mainly consisting of monkeys, to destroy balloons on a range of different maps. Bloons started its life as a flash game but this particuar version is a mobile port as far as I'm aware.

+Nice cartoony graphics
+The gameplay is very simple, you just place your towers in places where they can easily shoot incoming bloons and that's it, choosing the right tower is also important but again that's easy to learn
+Lots of towers
+All of the towers have a total of eight possible upgrades
+Upgrading a tower changes it's aestethic, usually quite drastically, which is nice and adds a bit of variety
+You can double the game speed if you so wish
+Lots of tracks
+Addictive gameplay
+Lots of hotkeys to make you more effecient
+The towers are very different to each other though most of them involve monkeys
+Suitable for all ages and it more directed to a younger audience (in my opinion)

-It feels a lot like a flash game which isn't overly surprising
-The maps are small which isn't great when it's such a fast paced game as the bloons go by very fast
-When you're playing a level there is a thick cartoon border which not only takes away space for the map but it never changes so it's incredibly boring to look at
-Waves have to be started manually and there's no countdown system like most TD games have, this really slows down gameplay unless you are completely focused on the game

Verdict:
7

A decent TD game that everyone should play at least once and of course is a must buy for fans of the original flash games.

reviewText:
Bloons TD5 is a full release of a popular browser game, Bloons Tower Defense. I hadn't heard of it, but the positive reviews and bright screenshots caught my eye when the price dropped to 75% off in a sale. When I installed the game and started it up, I got a message from no less than three friends stating their love of Bloons. I was also accused of living under a rock since I hadn't heard of it.

So, being a simple rock dweller who has not played the browser/flash versions of BTD, I can only give my opinion as a fan of tower defense games.

The premise, like most TD games, is simple, something is attacking, and you must defend! In this case, balloons are attacking. Their motives are unknown. Probably they wish to pillage our villages and take advantage of our women. If one slips by you, you lose a life and get that much closer to failing the level.

The balloons start out simple - regular red balloons you can pop with one hit. They quickly advance to multi-layered balloons, lead balloons that can only be popped by explosions, camouflaged balloons which must be detected, ceramic balloons, or even balloon blimps that explode into a myriad of other balloons when popped.

As you can guess, your defenses must advance as well! Starting from the simple dart thrower, you will advance to bomb towers, ninja monkeys who can see invisible enemies, minigun monkeys, mortar towers, glue guns to slow the horde of incoming balloons, or ships that can pull a whole blimp out of the sky. Every tower can be upgraded as well, and there are two upgrade paths you can choose to pursue. When you take all this into consideration with the fact there are 21 individual tower types, there are a TON of options and strategies.

There are also over 40 tracks, 4 difficulties, and the option to play each track in reverse. You can also use the currency you get for beating each track to unlock permanent upgrades to attributes such as attack speed, starting money, popping power, etc. or other bonuses such as Double Cash Mode, and one that increases the range of the Monkey Village (a tower that gives an aura increasing the power of your other towers).

My one qualm with the game is, it seems to get a bit too easy once you unlock Double Cash Mode and the Monkey Village range increase. It takes the game from a respectable challenge on normal difficulty, to very easy even on the harder difficulties. But there is still plenty of replay value, and I am still challenged on Impoppable (the hardest difficulty).

I also love the visual style, and it runs smoothly even when there are thousands of balloons on my screen. It will start to lag a bit if you get to the higher levels in freeplay mode. I also really appreciate some of the quality of life additions, like the option to automatically run through the levels (ie. skip the pause time in between levels) for experienced players. It's also handy for quick replays of easy missions.

I've got 30 hours on Bloons and I'm nowhere near done yet! One of the best $2.50 impulse buys I have made.

As the amount of bloons and their variations increase, the towers must be upgraded for more concise gameplay. The more medals you win, the more levels you unlock and the more achievements you earn. You also get monkey money that can be used to purchase extras or special agents" to be used in-game. It runs smoothly so there's no problems there. It's about time that I talked about this game indepth.

First of, I've been playing Monky Bloon Tower Defence games since the early stages of the internet. I've followed the series pretty close and if I could actually document the time I've invested into the game series..It would exceed 1000 easily. It's a pretty fly expansion into what has already become a successful story.

Pros:
*Lots of Towers to choose from. Some do better than others, but situations or maps will rise that you'll need to use the ones you don't normally use. A Submarine tower is introduced in this game and it's awesome.
*Spy Towers (Going back to the last point) are wonderful. Without spending any bananas (In game currency) and using the money you made on the last map, you can really put a good start on any difficulty. Different ones have different perks, but they are all immensely helpful for any difficulty or map.
*You now have the access to making one tower more powerful. Boomerang towers can throw two at one time or Bloon Chippers can stun every bloon that goes through it. It makes the game less dull.
*Maps are nicely made and the artwork is fluent. Putting the towers on any map isn't hard.
*The Replayability of this game is expansive. Achievement hunting is a thing. Also you now have Special Missions, Daily Challenges, and The Oasis (Which is just a Gauntlet of three/four maps for prizes/cash).
*When playing Solo, the game rarely lags.

Cons:
*One of my main problems with this game is the Co Op and the mechanics. Obviously it wasn't well thought out and let me explain why. You have limited communication, I MEAN you may as well be talking to yourself at this point. The only way to communicate with the other is to press a button that asks for money. So what ends up happening is, you have all these banana farms and your partner is clicking the button repeatedly. Often times, I can't give him any bananas because we're playing on Impoppable (The hardest mode) and I need factories for my side of the map to help me build larger towers. Most people will quit the game mid match and all that time you spent is waisted (either playing by yourself or finding another match for this to happen again). It really needs a chat window so I can tell the other partner what I'm going to do and what works best with my playstyle. (Minimalistic and Dangerous).
*The Lag in Co Op is awful. It doesn't happen until you get some serious business going on, but what happens is that you Pop faster than the computer can load. You often wait a full minute or two for a single round. People will disconnect due to this or just potato computers. It adds in A LOT of frustration.

Rate: Banana/10
If you like solo games that are cute, easy on the computer, and fun to play..I'd recommend this one. It takes a little time and its nice to get away from the big games that I play to come here and build towers. C:

Bloons TD 5 was my first encounter with the series and it's quite possibly the best tower defense game I've ever played - and I've played quite a few indeed. They've got an excellent gameplay formula. The tower diversity as well as upgrades to both the player as well as towers add a lot of flavor to tactical approach, and overall replayability is excellent.

That said, there are a couple fundamental flaws to watch out for:
-The first and perhaps most crippling is the random crashing that will occur if you're the sort of player that likes to squeese towers into tight spaces at the very border of the 'placeable areas'.
(Note to developers: I feel this likely has something to do with the coordinates arrays and warrants some looking in to.)
-The second is the net code. In many cases this isn't a very big problem, but on some poor connections to the other player, the client has trouble keeping up with game cash balance updates. There have been times I've had to wait as long as 5-10 minutes on the harder difficulties / longer games while the other player's balance was updated on my screen.

Both of these issues can be avoided however, so they should not necessarily sway your decision to get this game.
All in all, worth every penny of the $9.99 USD I paid for it.

4.5 / 5 *

Bloons TD 5 was my first encounter with the series and it's quite possibly the best tower defense game I've ever played - and I've played quite a few indeed. They've got an excellent gameplay formula. -The first and perhaps most crippling is the random crashing that will occur if you're the sort of player that likes to squeese towers into tight spaces at the very border of the 'placeable areas'.

-The second is the net code. In many cases this isn't a very big problem, but on some poor connections to the other player, the client has trouble keeping up with game cash balance updates. There have been times I've had to wait as long as 5-10 minutes on the harder difficulties / longer games while the other player's balance was updated on my screen.

Both of these issues can be avoided however, so they should not necessarily sway your decision to get this game.
All in all, worth every penny of the $9.99 USD I paid for it.

reviewText:
I like Plants vs Zombies a lot, but Bloons is probably my favorite tower defense game of all times. This charmingly cute game with cartoony graphics carries surprising depth and difficulty. I have in less than a week played more hours than I ever imagined. If you are considering buying this game, you can even try the flash version for free on ninjakiwi.com

The developers, from what I've seen, are very active and helpful on the forums and other communication platforms should you experience any issues. I haven't so far though.

The game, being a freemium game on the browser and with micro transactions on the mobile version, has everything available for in-game currency (and only in-game currency) on Steam. Any benefits that you may purchase can be deactivated, meaning that those that are more insane, such as the Double Cash Mode, can be disabled at any time to avoid the game being too easy while still being available in case you are struggling with a daily challenge or want to let your younger siblings or kids play.

Content-wise, there are over total 50 levels over five difficulties; Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced, Expert and Exteme. Each level can in turn be played in four different difficulties, all available both in normal and reverse paths. This should offer a challenge for both those new to tower defense games and the more experienced players.
There is also a simple coop mode, which simply splits the map and money in half, and allows you to hand money to the other player. You can play both with steam friends and a random quick match. While this doesn't offer that much new, it is very fun to be able to play with friends.
There are ten special missions available that make you think creatively, as well as 250 random missions with varying themes and difficulties. The special missions at least, are replayable at a lower rewards, in case you want to complete them differently, maybe with some perks disabled.
Along with all this content, there are also weekly odysseys, which are 3-5 levels(depending on difficulty) that you must complete in a row, rewarding great treasure, and daily challenges(which is to complete a level with only four available towers) at all four difficulties so you can earn some extra cash.
In short, there is no shortage of content and always a reason to return.

The downsides are that the levels are fairly repetitive - all difficulties have a set order of bloons incoming in the rounds. The option menu is also somewhat lacking, the only options being cloud upload/download, mute/unmute music, mute/unmute sound effects and windowed mode, as well as a language options and the ability to change controls between click and drop and drag and drop.

All in all, I would recommend the game to anyone, and at the current price it's basically a steal!

The developers, from what I've seen, are very active and helpful on the forums and other communication platforms should you experience any issues. I haven't so far though.

The game, being a freemium game on the browser and with micro transactions on the mobile version, has everything available for in-game currency (and only in-game currency) on Steam. Any benefits that you may purchase can be deactivated, meaning that those that are more insane, such as the Double Cash Mode, can be disabled at any time to avoid the game being too easy while still being available in case you are struggling with a daily challenge or want to let your younger siblings or kids play.

Content-wise, there are over total 50 levels over five difficulties; Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced, Expert and Exteme. Each level can in turn be played in four different difficulties, all available both in normal and reverse paths. This should offer a challenge for both those new to tower defense games and the more experienced players.
There is also a simple coop mode, which simply splits the map and money in half, and allows you to hand money to the other player. You can play both with steam friends and a random quick match. While this doesn't offer that much new, it is very fun to be able to play with friends.
There are ten special missions available that make you think creatively, as well as 250 random missions with varying themes and difficulties. The special missions at least, are replayable at a lower rewards, in case you want to complete them differently, maybe with some perks disabled.
Along with all this content, there are also weekly odysseys, which are 3-5 levels(depending on difficulty) that you must complete in a row, rewarding great treasure, and daily challenges(which is to complete a level with only four available towers) at all four difficulties so you can earn some extra cash.
In short, there is no shortage of content and always a reason to return.

The downsides are that the levels are fairly repetitive - all difficulties have a set order of bloons incoming in the rounds. The option menu is also somewhat lacking, the only options being cloud upload/download, mute/unmute music, mute/unmute sound effects and windowed mode, as well as a language options and the ability to change controls between click and drop and drag and drop.

All in all, I would recommend the game to anyone, and at the current price it's basically a steal!

I was impressed enough so that I preordered BTD5 Deluxe back when it came out. I am even more impressed now that not only do I have the pleasure of being able to play this game for free as a result of that, since they sent me a steam key for this game, but this version is even better. I was a rank 69 on Deluxe and I already know I'm going to get much higher than that on this game because it wasn't a simple remaster, but there were many other things that were changed as well, and I believe they were all for the better.

First off, right from the beginning, the title screen has been completely redesigned with all the deluxe upgrades being split up into two different categories. There is a new currency you earn as a result, in addition to the monkey money (that's what I call it, anyways). There are still no microtransactions and the upgrades dont feel extremely overpowered. They are small percentile bonuses that you can increase as you get more tokens. Tokens are unlocked by playing each track and higher difficulties yield more tokens.

In addition to the redesigned upgrade system, there are new tracks, towers, and even new special agents. There just appears to be something new everywhere. It's really quite surprising. To top it all off, seeing all the remastered tracks after playing the Deluxe version so much is really a treat. They really did a fantastic job on remastering these tracks. I recommend this game completely. 10/10

First of all I want to say that Bloons TD 5 is a great tower defence game however this version is just too insanely easy due to a major problem in game design. Namely the double cash mode.

The first couple days of playing this were great. A little bit of a grind to unlock everything but ultimately challenging and enjoyable. The moment you unlock double cash mode though the game basically plays itself. Hard levels become a breeze and on easy you seriously don't even see any bloons appearing on screen because they are all already dead from the dozen submarines or dartling guns you built by wave twenty.

With the normal cash mode the game feels well structured and balanced but with every token spent in the extra starting cash upgrade it becomes slightly easier and gives you more options to use. Then you spend $7500 on the double cash mode and all of that careful balance and design goes out the window immediately. It hardly even feels worthwhile playing it now.

It was then that I remembered that in the flash game double cash mode was a premium upgrade bought with real cash instead of ingame currency. In other words: pay to win. Between this, the token upgrades and the new overpowered towers the game rapidly becomes hugely unbalanced and completely without challenge.

Yes, you can turn this stuff off and play without it but the game gives you no reason not to use it. Some of the levels are almost certainly impossible on the hardest setting without these things turned on.

Ultimately then what you have is a game with two options:
1. Force yourself not to use the new content you have paid for in order to make the game a challenge until you eventually just get bored or infuriated with repeating the same level over and over and quit.
or:
2. Turn on double cash mode, build an entire fleet of submarines almost immediately and watch the game stutter to 20fps as they all fire in unison and beat the game for you.

Neither of these options seems very appealing to me anymore. If I had known the game was this broken I wouldn't have bothered buying it.

1: Why should I get this if it has a free Flash version?
Who gives a monkeys (pun intended) if this can be obtained as a free Flash game? Buying this goes straight to the developers so they can make this game more awesomer, as they themselves say.

This version has many more features, including the features from the old BTD5 Deluxe (yet to come) plus new towers, maps, offline play, premiums not costing real money, Monkey Lab, Impoppable difficulty, new special mission (No Escape) and more awesomeness.

2: What is BTD5? I haven't played the flash version.
You haven't? You're missing out. BTD5 is a tower defense game with large replayability, dozens of maps and special missions, funny art style, monkeys, special agents and more. If you prefer one tower over the rest, you can buy a plot of land for Monkey Money to make Speciality Buildings, which boosts one tower but makes it's supposed opposite more expensive.

There are 4 difficulty modes - Easy, Medium, Hard and Impoppable - plus some extra modes such as Deflation - where you get 50k cash and that's it, Apopalypse - where there's no pause between rounds and Sandbox - where you get infinite money and lives, and you spawn the bloons.

There are 14 types of bloon currently, ranging from the basic red bloon, to the armoured lead bloon, to the tough-as-nails ceramic to the fearsome Z.O.M.G.

There are many towers with different specialities and 2 paths of upgrades with 4 upgrades each. Once you have the third upgrade on one path, you can't have it on the other. Alongside these towers, there are road items which you can use when strapped of cash or a bloon has slipped through your defense.

3: It's expensive... :(
As I said, this version is worth the £7 ($10) price tag. Plus, if you had BTD5 Deluxe before this came out, you get this free. Could it be any better?

My final verdict: 94.5/100. When they add the BTD5 Deluxe missions and maps, it'll be 100.

This is a really fun tower defense game for about 20 - 30 hours, at which point you should have reached level 49 and have all the different tower upgrades. At that point there is still a lot to do in the game. In fact, way too much to do in the game. There are so many levels and power ups and achievements and whatnot that either you'll buckle down and decide to put the extra 50 - 100 hours playing all the levels, getting all the medals and everything else or you'll force yourself to write a review and delete the game.

Probably one of biggest pushes in the second direction was realizing that the strategies for each regular level don't need to vary so much for success. Special missions and daily challenges force you to get more creative but don't add a whole lot to making the game fun again. It's like continuing to play Mario 64 after you get the special triple jump - there's nothing really left to do except mess around, and there are just too many other games or things to do at this point to make a 30 hour game a 100 hour game.

Still, those were 30 good TD hours. Had the developers made me think it would have only taken 60 to get everything, I probably would have tricked myself into doing it.

This is a great game, nearly perfect, but the menus are not designed for PC. This is exceptionally frustrating considering how much time is wasted cumulatively just trying to get through the menus that are clearly designed for mobile platforms. These menus could be easily improved and would reduce the amount of time not playing significantly. The following questions help clarify these menu and GUI issues:

Why do I need to turn pages to see all the towers available?
Why do I need to go to settings to turn on auto-play when there is room all over the screen? To include the bars on the left and right making a 4:3 aspect ratio.
Why do I need to scroll through all the targeting priorities when you could easily click the one you want (like in the flash version)?
Why can't I select the maps or upgrades from an easy list rather than swiping optimized method (I know there is a sorting method but this is insufficient)?
Why is it that when I click on a tower next to another one, my selection alternates between the two when I am clearly clicking on only one of them?

Don't get me wrong, I will keep playing the game but the menus are absolutely frustrating. Play the free flash version, the extra towers and maps are not worth the cost (at least at full price), and definitely not worth the cost of time navigating. It is dissapointing, if the menus were actually made for PC this game could be an easy recommendation and very enjoyable.
